title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.15.34 | 20-12-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshurun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: The difficult to understand actions of the Lord Shri Krishna and his pure devotees.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam and highlights the difficulty in understanding the transcendental activities of Lord Krishna and his devotees, particularly the Yadu dynasty.

segments.key_quote: Srila Vishwanacharya Chakravarti Thakur explains that to give them relief from this mental agony Suta Goswami assured them that they will not suffer the pain of intoxication.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces Srila Prabhupada's purport and Vishwanatha Chakravarti Thakur's explanation of why the sages of Naimisharanya were disturbed by the account of the Yadus' demise, emphasizing the assurance that the Yadus did not suffer.

segments.key_quote: The Yadu dynasty members had appeared in the satchar traveling in satchar going through the satchar editing These must be the people who had come for knowledges in this world in order to assist the Lord in his leela of reducing the burden of this world
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Yadu dynasty members appeared to assist the Lord in reducing the burden of the world and that their demise was arranged by the Lord for them to return to their original position in the spiritual world.

segments.key_quote: It's not their Karma. It is the arrangement of the Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the role of demigods in the Yadu dynasty and how their relinquishing of their bodies through intoxication was arranged by the Lord, referencing the story of Kuvaira's sons.

themes: part and parcel of the Lord
segments.key_quote: For the Supreme Lord both the Asuras and the demigods are equal. Why? Both of them are his part and parcels.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that both asuras and demigods are part and parcel of the Lord, but the difference lies in their obedience, using the analogy of removing a thorn with another thorn.

segments.key_quote: So then the person to remove that thorn takes another thorn and and uses that second thorn to actually clear the skin in the area where the thorn is pricked
segments.summary: The speaker provides a detailed explanation of the thorn analogy, drawing on the practical experience of removing a thorn from one's foot in an agricultural setting.

segments.key_quote: Because whether he kills the asuras or protects the devatas, both are delivered by the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating the distinction between asuras and devatas, emphasizing the Lord's role in protecting the devatas and destroying the asuras, ultimately doing good to both by granting them liberation.
